clinical_study.brief_title: The Cardiovascular Effects of Air Pollution: the Role of Nitric Oxide
clinical_study.official_title: The Cardiovascular Effects of Air Pollution: the Role of Nitric Oxide

brief_summary.textblock: Exposure to air pollution has been linked to increased cardiorespiratory morbidity and mortality. The exact component of air pollution that mediates this effect is unknown, but the link is strongest for fine combustion derived particulate matter derived from traffic sources. Recently, it has been demonstrated that inhalation of diesel exhaust impairs vascular vasomotor tone and endogenous fibrinolysis. The mechanism underlying these detrimental vascular is unclear, but is thought to be via oxidative stress and altered bioavailability of endogenous nitric oxide. In these studies we plan to elucidate the role of endogenous nitric oxide (NO) in the adverse vascular responses observed following exposure to diesel exhaust.

primary_outcome.measure: Forearm blood flow as measured by venous occlusion plethysmography during infusion of NOS inhibitors and vasodilators

secondary_outcome.measure: Plasma concentrations of t-PA and PAI
secondary_outcome.time_frame: After infusion of bradykinin during forearm study

arm_group.description: 1 hour exposure to dilute diesel exhaust at a concentration of 300 µg/m3 with intermittent exercise
1 hour exposure to filtered air during intermittent exercise

intervention.description: Forearm venous occlusion plethysmography during intraarterial infusion of L-NMMA (2-8 µmol/min) followed by co-infusion of sodium nitroprusside (90-900 ng/min) as a "nitric oxide clamp". Forearm blood flow then measured during the clamp in response to infused vasodilators acetylcholine (5-20 mg/min), bradykinin (100-1000 pmol/min), verapamil (10-100 µg/min) and sodium nitroprusside (2-8 µg/min).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy volunteers
Exclusion Criteria:
- Use of regular medication (except oral contraceptive pill)
- Current smokers
- Significant occupational exposure to air pollution
- Intercurrent illness

reference.citation: Mills NL, Törnqvist H, Robinson SD, Gonzalez M, Darnley K, MacNee W, Boon NA, Donaldson K, Blomberg A, Sandstrom T, Newby DE. Diesel exhaust inhalation causes vascular dysfunction and impaired endogenous fibrinolysis. Circulation. 2005 Dec 20;112(25):3930-6.
